title: Aberdeen hires former shadow pensions minister
text:
Aberdeen Asset Management hires former shadow pensions minister Josephine Cumbo, Pensions Correspondent Comments 
Aberdeen Asset Management , Europe’s largest listed fund house, has hired Gregg McClymont, Labour’s former shadow pensions minister, to develop its pensions strategy in the UK. 
Mr McClymont, who was shadow pensions minister from 2011 to 2015, has been appointed head of retirement savings, a role created for the former MP who lost his seat in the May general election. More Shake-up of pensions tax relief considered 
On Tuesday, Mr McClymont, 39, said his new role would focus on developing Aberdeen’s strategy for “defined contribution” pensions, where savings are expected to grow significantly. 
“My focus will be on developing a strategy for Aberdeen in response to the new retirement market and ensuring the company is a significant player in that space,” he said. 
As shadow pensions minister, Mr McClymont campaigned for all pension schemes to acquire scale, reform their governance and deliver lower costs to savers. 
Mr McClymont said he remained a member of the Labour party, though was not politically active, and that Aberdeen shared his “strong pro-consumer views”. 
“Aberdeen are equally committed to developing good products at a fair price,” he said. 
In a 2013 paper for the leftwing Fabian society, Mr McClymont wrote that pensions in the UK were a “cottage industry in need of the efficiency and expertise that scaling up has produced in other countries”. Related Topics
